Patch Set 43: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged

I know that this is still WIP, but to save you time I should probably point out that this function already exists.  I would really prefer we don't recreate it, even if the existing one needs some refactoring to separate out the Response object from the call api.  We've already seen cases where having multiple versions of these things creates drift over time when properties get added to one and not the other, so making sure we're generating the same object from the same code seems like a good idea.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/f056d96a7c4d54f3e7d5ef92bd501f8cd6edb432/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1416

When you point it out like this, i noticed that i degraded the dbus properties to 'std::string'. I assume that the dbus event log entries need a new struct anyways, since their id is not 'string' and timestamp is also not 'string'.

But yes the function to extract it from dbus should only exist once.
I addressed this in a new patch below this one.
"?" is certainly not what the redfish spec specifies for message args.
ok, leaving it empty then, as is done for the current GET handler for the dbus event logs.
why optional and unique_ptr?  What does each represent?

optional, as it's only relevant when using dbus event logs.
unique_ptr, as this pointer is owning the match instance.

optional is also an owning template.  Please respond with

what does the following 3 states mean
dbusEventLogMonitor == nullopt
*dbusEventLogMonitor == nullptr
*dbusEventLogMonitor is populated


I suspect the first two states can be combined into one.
ok, replaced it with just the unique pointer.
This still looks like WIP?
removed this code.
a little text here about what is being printed would be good.  Just printing a value with no context isn't the best.
Added a small message 👍.

Use a string_view here.  string will construct and malloc every loop.

also, I suspect we could just drop the logEntryInterface variable altogether and we'd save a line.
yes, we can just compare to the string literal 👍
do we need this variable?  Can we just pass dbusEventLogMatchHandler directly?
i think it's valuable to convey that this is a callback in the call below.

dbusEventLogMatchHandler is already a callback of the same type.  THere's no need to have a second local variable of the same type.  If the value is truly in the name "callback" then lets rename dbusEventLogMatchHandler -> dbusEventLogMatchCallback

But making a copy of this possibly large struct doesn't seem like a good idea.
ok, i inlined that 👍
Cool.  Sounds like this needs to be marked as WIP until then?

No, it is my understanding that this was explicitly requested to go in and eventually get completed when the mapping is ready to correctly initialize the MessageArgs.

I can remove the 'MessageArgs' property from the response, as is already done in
function 'dBusEventLogEntryGet'
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/a14c9113226dcae33a36eb4e50abbcc28be998ae/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1760

is that what you want?

We cannot check in code that produces redfish that's hardcoded wrong and breaks existing systems.  MessageArgs isn't a required field in redfish if messageId doesn't exist, so yeah, omitting is should be fine.
I interpret this as resolved, please un-resolve if there's still any issue.
what does this mean?
The order of 'MessageArgs' provided via 'AdditionalData' on dbus is not correct.
Lets just remove all mention of messageargs.  It's unimportant to this commit.
Done
Any way to test this without directly creating a dbus entry?  Maybe triggering a real event (like a reboot) instead?
It depends on which daemons generate phosphor-logging events. I'm not aware of any overview or complete list. Patrick would probably have an idea on this.
Cool.  Lets leave this open until the commit message is updated with a functional test.

I'm implementing in bmcweb here, not in other daemons.

If other daemons create the log entry or not, it does not matter to this implementation. The implementation is about the dbus log entries, their dbus interface, consuming that in bmcweb and exposing it via redfish.

Relying on another daemon to produce a specific log entry or produce one at all creates a problem for the reproducibility of that manual test. 

Is there any log entry instance that you think the implementation would fail on?

> I'm implementing in bmcweb here, not in other daemons.

Cool, and bmcweb has had a history of failures that were caused essentially because someone injected their idealized dbus interface in a test, and ignored what the backends actually produced.  The way we've found to defend against that in code review is to ask for a test that acts as a user would, actually generating a real event.

> 
> If other daemons create the log entry or not, it does not matter to this implementation. The implementation is about the dbus log entries, their dbus interface, consuming that in bmcweb and exposing it via redfish.
> 
> Relying on another daemon to produce a specific log entry or produce one at all creates a problem for the reproducibility of that manual test.

Functionally, we have to rely on other daemons to produce expected log entries.  As a concrete example, it's been brought up before about 2 vs 3 digits in the registry version number.  Your test does 2, which is fine, but there's no way to verify that's what daemons actually produce.

> 
> Is there any log entry instance that you think the implementation would fail on?

Without testthe code in the backend, there's not really any way to know.

I see the same event log entries from my manual test also in the webui.
```
https://${bmc}/#/logs/event-logs
```

So it has to have the same dbus properties.

Since i am using the same functions to parse it

```
+        std::optional<DbusEventLogEntry> optEntry =
+            fillDbusEventLogEntryFromPropertyMap(map);
```

How would there be a difference?

> Cool, and bmcweb has had a history of failures that were caused essentially because someone injected their idealized dbus interface in a test, and ignored what the backends actually produced.

I'm simply exposing, via event subscriptions, the same dbus event log entries which are already supported. Not  inventing any new dbus interfaces here.


If you want to see something which produces these entries, how did you come to merge the support for dbus event log originally?

> I see the same event log entries from my manual test also in the webui.
> ```
> https://${bmc}/#/logs/event-logs
> ```
> 
> So it has to have the same dbus properties.
> 
> Since i am using the same functions to parse it
> 
> ```
> +        std::optional<DbusEventLogEntry> optEntry =
> +            fillDbusEventLogEntryFromPropertyMap(map);
> ```
> 
> How would there be a difference?
> 
> > Cool, and bmcweb has had a history of failures that were caused essentially because someone injected their idealized dbus interface in a test, and ignored what the backends actually produced.
> 
> I'm simply exposing, via event subscriptions, the same dbus event log entries which are already supported. Not  inventing any new dbus interfaces here.
> 
> 
> If you want to see something which produces these entries, how did you come to merge the support for dbus event log originally?

Because the person that pushed the review tested it, and provided a testing statement in their commit message that tested a real scenario, just like I'm asking you to do.
making a meson option for this as discussed.

Can you rewrite your test a little to remove the parts that don't actually effect the outside interface?  For example, "makes it through the filtering code" I'm not really sure what that means, and isn't really relevant to your test.

There is event filtration happening based on the properties set for the event subscription. So it's quite important we go through that, otherwise the event will not come out on the other side.

So it is affecting the outside interface.

if you're going to test filtering, then add it to your test by imposing filters.  What's written here doesn't really test anything.  If you're not going to test filters, then no need to mention it in your tested statement.
We should really look at breaking this class down a bit to make clear the two backends.

instructions unclear. Is this something i should do?

If so, how should the separation look like, in terms of files and classes.

Break out the methods for DBus access that are separate from filesystem access.  Today they're all in this class, which wasn't great when we only supported one path, but really is a problem when we add a second path.  I'd expect 3 classes

EventServiceManager
DbusEventLog
FileSystemEventLog

I'd really prefer we don't do that.  bmcweb has a relatively complete understanding of what exists within it.  The need for abstract interfaces is fairly rare by design.

From the documentation for MessageArgs:

```It has the same semantics as the `MessageArgs` property in the Redfish `MessageRegistry` schema```

Which I read to mean omitting it for a message that has it specified in the equivalent registry would be a spec violation.

i found the cited schema here, 
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/MessageRegistry.v1_6_3.json

found this text regarding the message.

> "This property shall contain the message to display.  If a %integer is included in part of the string, it shall represent a string substitution for any `MessageArgs` that accompany the message, in order."

From my interpretation, the spec is clear that 'MessageArgs' is not a required property.

> This property shall contain an array of message arguments that are
substituted for the arguments in the message when looked up in the
message registry.

"shall" means required, but that applies to the contents of the 'MessageArgs' field.

If the spec authors would have had your interpretation in mind, the property 'MessageArgs' would be 'required' and then the empty array would be present in case there are no message args for a message?

If we currently have no way to get the 'MessageArgs' in the correct order from dbus, what choice do we have?

If a redfish client depends on the existence of an optional property, that client is broken, right?
Like we talked about on discord, because the base message has no messageid, it's ok for us to omit messageargs here.
Please log something here if this is unexpected.
Done

We probably shouldn't unconditionally be registering for events.  Take a look at the flow of registerMetricReportSignal and unregisterMetricReportSignal

They check for number of subscribers, and only subscribe if someone is actually listening.

Why would we introduce the conditional flow and make it complicated?

If we would do it that way then we would have to check that upon creation of a new subscription the match is created.

So the point of failure is moved into the future. I would rather have
this setup be done at startup.

If there is any problem with creating the match, it will fail fast.
Following your commit on this, so this should be resolved.
This doesn't really do what we want.  We don't want to monitor events if nobody is listening.  Take a look at my patch, which obsoletes this.
